vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
It was found that apt-key in apt, all versions, do not correctly validate gpg keys with the master keyring, leading to a potential man-in-the-middle attack.

## References

- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2011-3374)
- [MISC](https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2011/CVE-2011-3374.html)
- [MISC](https://snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-LINUX-APT-116518)
- [RedHat CVE Database](https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2011-3374)
vulnerabilities.name: apt/libapt-pkg5.0
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An issue was discovered in disable_priv_mode in shell.c in GNU Bash through 5.0 patch 11. By default, if Bash is run with its effective UID not equal to its real UID, it will drop privileges by setting its effective UID to its real UID. However, it does so incorrectly. On Linux and other systems that support "saved UID" functionality, the saved UID is not dropped. An attacker with command execution in the shell can use "enable -f" for runtime loading of a new builtin, which can be a shared object that calls setuid() and therefore regains privileges. However, binaries running with an effective UID of 0 are unaffected.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-18276)
- [GitHub Commit](https://github.com/bminor/bash/commit/951bdaad7a18cc0dc1036bba86b18b90874d39ff)
- [MISC](http://packetstormsecurity.com/files/155498/Bash-5.0-Patch-11-Privilege-Escalation.html)
- [MISC](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-wGtxJ8opa8)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2019-18276)
vulnerabilities.name: bash
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Check for Dropped Privileges

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
chroot in GNU coreutils, when used with --userspec, allows local users to escape to the parent session via a crafted TIOCSTI ioctl call, which pushes characters to the terminal's input buffer.

- [OSS security Advisory](http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2016/02/28/2)

vulnerabilities.name: coreutils
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Input Validation

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
In GNU Coreutils through 8.29, chown-core.c in chown and chgrp does not prevent replacement of a plain file with a symlink during use of the POSIX "-R -L" options, which allows local users to modify the ownership of arbitrary files by leveraging a race condition.

## References
- [CVE Details](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-18018)
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2017-18018)
- [http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/coreutils/2017-12/msg00045.html](http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/coreutils/2017-12/msg00045.html)
vulnerabilities.name: coreutils
vulnerabilities.title: Race Condition

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
stack_protect_prologue in cfgexpand.c and stack_protect_epilogue in function.c in GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) 4.1 through 8 (under certain circumstances) generate instruction sequences when targeting ARM targets that spill the address of the stack protector guard, which allows an attacker to bypass the protection of -fstack-protector, -fstack-protector-all, -fstack-protector-strong, and -fstack-protector-explicit against stack overflow by controlling what the stack canary is compared against.

## References
- [CONFIRM](https://gcc.gnu.org/viewcvs/gcc/trunk/gcc/config/arm/arm-protos.h?revision=266379&view=markup)
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2018-12886)
- [MISC](https://www.gnu.org/software/gcc/gcc-8/changes.html)
vulnerabilities.name: gcc-8/libstdc++6
vulnerabilities.title: Out-of-Bounds

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
The POWER9 backend in GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) before version 10 could optimize multiple calls of the __builtin_darn intrinsic into a single call, thus reducing the entropy of the random number generator. This occurred because a volatile operation was not specified. For example, within a single execution of a program, the output of every __builtin_darn() call may be the same.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-15847)
- [MISC](https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=91481)
- [OpenSuse Security Announcement](http://lists.opensuse.org/opensuse-security-announce/2019-10/msg00056.html)
- [OpenSuse Security Announcement](http://lists.opensuse.org/opensuse-security-announce/2019-10/msg00057.html)
vulnerabilities.name: gcc-8/libstdc++6
vulnerabilities.title: Insufficient Entropy

## Overview
** DISPUTED ** In the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.29, check_dst_limits_calc_pos_1 in posix/regexec.c has Uncontrolled Recursion, as demonstrated by '(|)(\\1\\1)*' in grep, a different issue than CVE-2018-20796. NOTE: the software maintainer disputes that this is a vulnerability because the behavior occurs only with a crafted pattern.

## Overview
Stack consumption vulnerability in the regcomp implementation in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.11.3, and 2.12.x through 2.12.2, allows context-dependent attackers to cause a denial of service (resource exhaustion) via a regular expression containing adjacent repetition operators, as demonstrated by a {10,}{10,}{10,}{10,} sequence in the proftpd.gnu.c exploit for ProFTPD.

The glob implementation in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) allows remote authenticated users to cause a denial of service (CPU and memory consumption) via crafted glob expressions that do not match any pathnames, as demonstrated by glob expressions in STAT commands to an FTP daemon, a different vulnerability than CVE-2010-2632.

- [http://securityreason.com/exploitalert/9223](http://securityreason.com/exploitalert/9223)

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An exploitable signed comparison vulnerability exists in the ARMv7 memcpy() implementation of GNU glibc 2.30.9000. Calling memcpy() (on ARMv7 targets that utilize the GNU glibc implementation) with a negative value for the 'num' parameter results in a signed comparison vulnerability. If an attacker underflows the 'num' parameter to memcpy(), this vulnerability could lead to undefined behavior such as writing to out-of-bounds memory and potentially remote code execution. Furthermore, this memcpy() implementation allows for program execution to continue in scenarios where a segmentation fault or crash should have occurred. The dangers occur in that subsequent execution and iterations of this code will be executed with this corrupted data.

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An exploitable signed comparison vulnerability exists in the ARMv7 memcpy() implementation of GNU glibc 2.30.9000. Calling memcpy() (on ARMv7 targets that utilize the GNU glibc implementation) with a negative value for the 'num' parameter results in a signed comparison vulnerability. If an attacker underflows the 'num' parameter to memcpy(), this vulnerability could lead to undefined behavior such as writing to out-of-bounds memory and potentially remote code execution. Furthermore, this memcpy() implementation allows for program execution to continue in scenarios where a segmentation fault or crash should have occurred. The dangers occur in that subsequent execution and iterations of this code will be executed with this corrupted data.

## References
- [ADVISORY](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2020-6096)
- [MISC](https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25620)

## Overview
The SSL protocol, as used in certain configurations in Microsoft Windows and Microsoft Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, Google Chrome, Opera, and other products, encrypts data by using CBC mode with chained initialization vectors, which allows man-in-the-middle attackers to obtain plaintext HTTP headers via a blockwise chosen-boundary attack (BCBA) on an HTTPS session, in conjunction with JavaScript code that uses (1) the HTML5 WebSocket API, (2) the Java URLConnection API, or (3) the Silverlight WebClient API, aka a "BEAST" attack.

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
GnuTLS 3.6.x before 3.6.13 uses incorrect cryptography for DTLS. The earliest affected version is 3.6.3 (2018-07-16) because of an error in a 2017-10-06 commit. The DTLS client always uses 32 '\0' bytes instead of a random value, and thus contributes no randomness to a DTLS negotiation. This breaks the security guarantees of the DTLS protocol.

## References

- [MISC](https://gitlab.com/gnutls/gnutls/-/issues/960)
- [MISC](https://www.gnutls.org/security-new.html%23GNUTLS-SA-2020-03-31)

vulnerabilities.name: gnutls28/libgnutls30
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Input Validation

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
GnuTLS 3.6.x before 3.6.13 uses incorrect cryptography for DTLS. The earliest affected version is 3.6.3 (2018-07-16) because of an error in a 2017-10-06 commit. The DTLS client always uses 32 '\0' bytes instead of a random value, and thus contributes no randomness to a DTLS negotiation. This breaks the security guarantees of the DTLS protocol.

## References
- [ADVISORY](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2020-11501)
- [DEBIAN](https://www.debian.org/security/2020/dsa-4652)
- [MISC](https://gitlab.com/gnutls/gnutls/-/commit/5b595e8e52653f6c5726a4cdd8fddeb6e83804d2)
- [MISC](https://gitlab.com/gnutls/gnutls/-/issues/960)
- [MISC](https://www.gnutls.org/security-new.html%23GNUTLS-SA-2020-03-31)

vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2020-11501

## Overview
extensions/libxt_tcp.c in iptables through 1.4.21 does not match TCP SYN+FIN packets in --syn rules, which might allow remote attackers to bypass intended firewall restrictions via crafted packets.  NOTE: the CVE-2012-6638 fix makes this issue less relevant.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2012-2663)
- [RedHat Bugzilla Bug](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=826702)

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
A buffer overflow in iptables-restore in netfilter iptables 1.8.2 allows an attacker to (at least) crash the program or potentially gain code execution via a specially crafted iptables-save file. This is related to add_param_to_argv in xshared.c.

## References
- [CONFIRM](https://git.netfilter.org/iptables/commit/iptables/xshared.c?id=2ae1099a42e6a0f06de305ca13a842ac83d4683e)
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-11360)
- [MISC](https://0day.work/cve-2019-11360-bufferoverflow-in-iptables-restore-v1-8-2/)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2019-11360)
vulnerabilities.name: iptables/libxtables12
vulnerabilities.title: Out-of-Bounds

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
cipher/elgamal.c in Libgcrypt through 1.8.2, when used to encrypt messages directly, improperly encodes plaintexts, which allows attackers to obtain sensitive information by reading ciphertext data (i.e., it does not have semantic security in face of a ciphertext-only attack). The Decisional Diffie-Hellman (DDH) assumption does not hold for Libgcrypt's ElGamal implementation.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2018-6829)
- [MISC](https://github.com/weikengchen/attack-on-libgcrypt-elgamal)
- [MISC](https://github.com/weikengchen/attack-on-libgcrypt-elgamal/wiki)
- [MISC](https://lists.gnupg.org/pipermail/gcrypt-devel/2018-February/004394.html)
- [MISC](https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/cpujan2020.html)

vulnerabilities.title: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
In Libgcrypt 1.8.4, the C implementation of AES is vulnerable to a flush-and-reload side-channel attack because physical addresses are available to other processes. (The C implementation is used on platforms where an assembly-language implementation is unavailable.)

## References

- [GitHub Commit](https://github.com/gpg/libgcrypt/commit/a4c561aab1014c3630bc88faf6f5246fee16b020)
- [GitHub Commit](https://github.com/gpg/libgcrypt/commit/daedbbb5541cd8ecda1459d3b843ea4d92788762)

- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2019-12904)

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
GNU libidn2 before 2.2.0 fails to perform the roundtrip checks specified in RFC3490 Section 4.2 when converting A-labels to U-labels. This makes it possible in some circumstances for one domain to impersonate another. By creating a malicious domain that matches a target domain except for the inclusion of certain punycoded Unicode characters (that would be discarded when converted first to a Unicode label and then back to an ASCII label), arbitrary domains can be impersonated.

## References
- [CONFIRM](https://gitlab.com/libidn/libidn2/commit/614117ef6e4c60e1950d742e3edf0a0ef8d389de)
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-12290)
- [MISC](https://gitlab.com/libidn/libidn2/commit/241e8f486134793cb0f4a5b0e5817a97883401f5)
- [MISC](https://gitlab.com/libidn/libidn2/merge_requests/71)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2019-12290)
- [Ubuntu Security Advisory](https://usn.ubuntu.com/4168-1/)

## Overview
libseccomp before 2.4.0 did not correctly generate 64-bit syscall argument comparisons using the arithmetic operators (LT, GT, LE, GE), which might able to lead to bypassing seccomp filters and potential privilege escalations.

## Overview
GNU Libtasn1-4.13 libtasn1-4.13 version libtasn1-4.13, libtasn1-4.12 contains a DoS, specifically CPU usage will reach 100% when running asn1Paser against the POC due to an issue in _asn1_expand_object_id(p_tree), after a long time, the program will be killed. This attack appears to be exploitable via parsing a crafted file.

## Overview
GNU Libtasn1-4.13 libtasn1-4.13 version libtasn1-4.13, libtasn1-4.12 contains a DoS, specifically CPU usage will reach 100% when running asn1Paser against the POC due to an issue in _asn1_expand_object_id(p_tree), after a long time, the program will be killed. This attack appears to be exploitable via parsing a crafted file.

vulnerabilities.name: shadow/passwd
vulnerabilities.title: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU)

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An issue was discovered in shadow 4.5. newgidmap (in shadow-utils) is setuid and allows an unprivileged user to be placed in a user namespace where setgroups(2) is permitted. This allows an attacker to remove themselves from a supplementary group, which may allow access to certain filesystem paths if the administrator has used "group blacklisting" (e.g., chmod g-rwx) to restrict access to paths. This flaw effectively reverts a security feature in the kernel (in particular, the /proc/self/setgroups knob) to prevent this sort of privilege escalation.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2018-7169)
- [Gentoo Security Advisory](https://security.gentoo.org/glsa/201805-09)
- [MISC](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/%2Bsource/shadow/%2Bbug/1729357)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2018-7169)
vulnerabilities.name: shadow/passwd
vulnerabilities.title: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
initscripts in rPath Linux 1 sets insecure permissions for the /var/log/btmp file, which allows local users to obtain sensitive information regarding authentication attempts.  NOTE: because sshd detects the insecure permissions and does not log certain events, this also prevents sshd from logging failed authentication attempts by remote attackers.

## References
- [BUGTRAQ](http://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/482129/100/100/threaded)
- [BUGTRAQ](http://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/482857/100/0/threaded)
- [CONFIRM](https://issues.rpath.com/browse/RPL-1825)
- [Dead Link](http://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/archive/1/482129/100/100/threaded)
- [Dead Link](http://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/archive/1/482857/100/0/threaded)
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2007-5686)
- [Secunia Advisory](http://secunia.com/advisories/27215)
- [Security Focus](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/26048)
- [VUPEN](http://www.vupen.com/english/advisories/2007/3474)
vulnerabilities.name: shadow/passwd
vulnerabilities.title: Access Restriction Bypass

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
shadow 4.8, in certain circumstances affecting at least Gentoo, Arch Linux, and Void Linux, allows local users to obtain root access because setuid programs are misconfigured. Specifically, this affects shadow 4.8 when compiled using --with-libpam but without explicitly passing --disable-account-tools-setuid, and without a PAM configuration suitable for use with setuid account management tools. This combination leads to account management tools (groupadd, groupdel, groupmod, useradd, userdel, usermod) that can easily be used by unprivileged local users to escalate privileges to root in multiple ways. This issue became much more relevant in approximately December 2019 when an unrelated bug was fixed (i.e., the chmod calls to suidusbins were fixed in the upstream Makefile which is now included in the release version 4.8).

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-19882)
- [GitHub Commit](https://github.com/shadow-maint/shadow/commit/edf7547ad5aa650be868cf2dac58944773c12d75)
- [GitHub PR](https://github.com/shadow-maint/shadow/pull/199)
- [GitHub PR](https://github.com/void-linux/void-packages/pull/17580)
- [MISC](https://bugs.archlinux.org/task/64836)
- [MISC](https://bugs.gentoo.org/702252)

This issue became much more relevant in approximately December 2019 when an unrelated bug was fixed (i.e., the chmod calls to suidusbins were fixed in the upstream Makefile which is now included in the release version 4.8).

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-19882)
- [GitHub Commit](https://github.com/shadow-maint/shadow/commit/edf7547ad5aa650be868cf2dac58944773c12d75)
- [GitHub PR](https://github.com/shadow-maint/shadow/pull/199)
- [GitHub PR](https://github.com/void-linux/void-packages/pull/17580)
- [MISC](https://bugs.archlinux.org/task/64836)
- [MISC](https://bugs.gentoo.org/702252)

vulnerabilities.name: shadow/login
vulnerabilities.title: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU)

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An issue was discovered in shadow 4.5. newgidmap (in shadow-utils) is setuid and allows an unprivileged user to be placed in a user namespace where setgroups(2) is permitted. This allows an attacker to remove themselves from a supplementary group, which may allow access to certain filesystem paths if the administrator has used "group blacklisting" (e.g., chmod g-rwx) to restrict access to paths. This flaw effectively reverts a security feature in the kernel (in particular, the /proc/self/setgroups knob) to prevent this sort of privilege escalation.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2018-7169)
- [Gentoo Security Advisory](https://security.gentoo.org/glsa/201805-09)
- [MISC](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/%2Bsource/shadow/%2Bbug/1729357)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2018-7169)
vulnerabilities.name: shadow/login
vulnerabilities.title: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
initscripts in rPath Linux 1 sets insecure permissions for the /var/log/btmp file, which allows local users to obtain sensitive information regarding authentication attempts.  NOTE: because sshd detects the insecure permissions and does not log certain events, this also prevents sshd from logging failed authentication attempts by remote attackers.

## References
- [BUGTRAQ](http://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/482129/100/100/threaded)

vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2019-9619

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
It was discovered that a systemd service that uses DynamicUser property can get new privileges through the execution of SUID binaries, which would allow to create binaries owned by the service transient group with the setgid bit set. A local attacker may use this flaw to access resources that will be owned by a potentially different service in the future, when the GID will be recycled.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-3844)
- [Netapp Security Advisory](https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20190619-0002/)
- [RedHat Bugzilla Bug](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2019-3844)
- [Security Focus](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/108096)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2019-3844)
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0
vulnerabilities.title: Access Restriction Bypass

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
It was discovered that a systemd service that uses DynamicUser property can create a SUID/SGID binary that would be allowed to run as the transient service UID/GID even after the service is terminated. A local attacker may use this flaw to access resources that will be owned by a potentially different service in the future, when the UID/GID will be recycled.

vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0
vulnerabilities.title: Access Restriction Bypass

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
systemd 242 changes the VT1 mode upon a logout, which allows attackers to read cleartext passwords in certain circumstances, such as watching a shutdown, or using Ctrl-Alt-F1 and Ctrl-Alt-F2. This occurs because the KDGKBMODE (aka current keyboard mode) check is mishandled.

vulnerabilities.title: Missing Release of Resource after Effective Lifetime

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
A heap use-after-free vulnerability was found in systemd before version v245-rc1, where asynchronous Polkit queries are performed while handling dbus messages. A local unprivileged attacker can abuse this flaw to crash systemd services or potentially execute code and elevate their privileges, by sending specially crafted dbus messages.

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
It was discovered that a systemd service that uses DynamicUser property can create a SUID/SGID binary that would be allowed to run as the transient service UID/GID even after the service is terminated. A local attacker may use this flaw to access resources that will be owned by a potentially different service in the future, when the UID/GID will be recycled.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-3843)
- [Fedora Security Update](https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce@lists.fedoraproject.org/message/5JXQAKSTMABZ46EVCRMW62DHWYHTTFES/)
- [Netapp Security Advisory](https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20190619-0002/)
- [RedHat Bugzilla Bug](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2019-3843)
- [Security Focus](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/108116)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2019-3843)
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0
vulnerabilities.title: Access Restriction Bypass

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
systemd 242 changes the VT1 mode upon a logout, which allows attackers to read cleartext passwords in certain circumstances, such as watching a shutdown, or using Ctrl-Alt-F1 and Ctrl-Alt-F2. This occurs because the KDGKBMODE (aka current keyboard mode) check is mishandled.

## References
- [BID](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/108389)
- [CONFIRM](https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20190530-0002/)
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2018-20839)
- [MISC](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/%2Bsource/systemd/%2Bbug/1803993)
- [MISC](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/9725f1a10f80f5e0ae7d9b60547458622aeb322f)
- [MISC](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/pull/12378)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2018-20839)
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0
vulnerabilities.title: Credentials Management

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
An issue was discovered in button_open in login/logind-button.c in systemd before 243. When executing the udevadm trigger command, a memory leak may occur.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-20386)
- [GitHub Commit](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/b2774a3ae692113e1f47a336a6c09bac9cfb49ad)
- [Netapp Security Advisory](https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20200210-0002/)
- [OpenSuse Security Announcement](http://lists.opensuse.org/opensuse-security-announce/2020-02/msg00014.html)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2019-20386)
- [Ubuntu Security Advisory](https://usn.ubuntu.com/4269-1/)
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0
vulnerabilities.title: Missing Release of Resource after Effective Lifetime

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
A heap use-after-free vulnerability was found in systemd before version v245-rc1, where asynchronous Polkit queries are performed while handling dbus messages. A local unprivileged attacker can abuse this flaw to crash systemd services or potentially execute code and elevate their privileges, by sending specially crafted dbus messages.

## References
- [CONFIRM](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2020-1712)
- [CONFIRM](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/1068447e6954dc6ce52f099ed174c442cb89ed54)
- [CONFIRM](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/637486261528e8aa3da9f26a4487dc254f4b7abb)
- [CONFIRM](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/bc130b6858327b382b07b3985cf48e2aa9016b2d)
- [CONFIRM](https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/ea0d0ede03c6f18dbc5036c5e9cccf97e415ccc2)
- [CONFIRM](https://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2020/02/05/1)
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2020-1712)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2020-1712)
vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libsystemd0
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2020-1712

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
systemd, when updating file permissions, allows local users to change the permissions and SELinux security contexts for arbitrary files via a symlink attack on unspecified files.

## References
- [Debian Bug Report](http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=725357)
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2013-4392)
- [OSS security Advisory](http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2013/10/01/9)
- [RedHat Bugzilla Bug](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=859060)

vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libudev1
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2019-9619

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
It was discovered that a systemd service that uses DynamicUser property can get new privileges through the execution of SUID binaries, which would allow to create binaries owned by the service transient group with the setgid bit set. A local attacker may use this flaw to access resources that will be owned by a potentially different service in the future, when the GID will be recycled.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-3844)
- [Netapp Security Advisory](https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20190619-0002/)
- [RedHat Bugzilla Bug](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2019-3844)
- [Security Focus](http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/108096)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2019-3844)

vulnerabilities.name: systemd/libudev1
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2020-1712

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
Tar 1.15.1 does not properly warn the user when extracting setuid or setgid files, which may allow local users or remote attackers to gain privileges.

This is considered intended behaviour, as tar is an archiving tool and one needs to give `-p` as a command line flag

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2005-2541)
- [HP Security Bulletin](http://marc.info/?l=bugtraq&m=112327628230258&w=2)
vulnerabilities.name: tar
vulnerabilities.title: CVE-2005-2541

vulnerabilities.description:
## Overview
pax_decode_header in sparse.c in GNU Tar before 1.32 had a NULL pointer dereference when parsing certain archives that have malformed extended headers.

## References
- [Debian Security Tracker](https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2019-9923)
- [MISC](http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/tar.git/commit/?id=cb07844454d8cc9fb21f53ace75975f91185a120)
- [MISC](http://savannah.gnu.org/bugs/?55369)
- [MISC](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/%2Bsource/tar/%2Bbug/1810241)
- [OpenSuse Security Announcement](http://lists.opensuse.org/opensuse-security-announce/2019-04/msg00077.html)
- [Ubuntu CVE Tracker](http://people.ubuntu.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/CVE-2019-9923)
vulnerabilities.name: tar
vulnerabilities.title: NULL Pointer Dereference
